description.narrative: Identificación de productos financieros estandarizados e implementación de los componentes del Programa Inclusivo de Desarrollo Rural - PRIDER.
capital of a political entity
policy, planning and administration

Número de productos financieros estructurados identificados. Número de programa de uniones de crédito y ahorro (UNICA). Número de familias atendidas con el programa UNICA.
Indicadores para 2013: 120 UNICAS conformadas y en funcionamiento en Lambayeque, Ayacucho e Ica.

comment.narrative: Identificación de la zona piloto conformada por los distritos de Zaña, Cayaltí y Nueva Arica para implementar el Programa - PRIDER. Linea de base para 2013: Lambayeque: Al cierre del año 2012, se han constituido 51 Uniones de Crédito y Ahorro – UNICAs. Ica y Ayacucho: No hay UNICAS.

Producto 1. 1. 50% de UNICAS en funcionamiento en Lambayeque e Ica en 2013 se gradúan 2. 95% de UNICAS creadas en Ayacucho en 2014 están operativas y se crea 80 UNICAS nuevas. 3. Al menos 70% de mujeres como miembros de UNICAS; al menos 55% cargos directivos ocupados por mujeres; al menos 40% de préstamos otorgados a mujeres. Producto 2: Actividad 2.1: 7,500 personas capacitadas en la Tabla de Negocios. Actividad 2.1: Al menos 40% de mujeres capacitadas en tablas de negocios Actividad 2.2: 14,000 asistentes a la Feria del Emprendedor Actividad 2.4: 60 escuelas participan en el programa de Escuelas Emprendedoras y lo finalizan. Actividad 2.4: 20,000 estudiantes participan en el programa de Escuelas Emprendedoras. Actividad 2.4: Al menos 50% de niñas como participantes en programa de escuelas emprendedoras Actividad 2.5: 200 de emprendedores rurales capacitados y certificados (sectores a los que pertenecen). Actividad 2.5. 40 % de mujeres entre emprendedores rurales capacitados y certificados. Producto 3: Actividad 3.1: Al menos 7% de nuevos usuarios (2014) establecen contacto comercial con Ecuador Actividad 3.2: Versión 3.0 del Portal web en funcionamiento

2015 (anual): Producto 1. 1. 44% de UNICAS de Lambayeque y 89% de Ica se gradúan. 2. 20 nuevas UNICAS en Ayacucho, con participación de 252 personas. No hay información sobre operatividad de UNICAS creadas en 2014. 3. Participación de la mujer en Ayacucho: 67% membresía de UNICAS; 54% en cargos directivos; por confirmar participación en préstamos.
Producto 2: Actividad 2.1: Capacitaciones llevadas a cabo en enero y junio: 2,800 personas inscritas. Actividad 2.1: COFIDE prove información incompleta; por determinar. Actividad 2.2: Feria se realizará en noviembre Actividad 2.4: N/A. Actividad 2.4: N/A. Actividad 2.4: N/A Actividad 2.5: N/A Actividad 2.5. N/A. Producto 3: Actividad 3.1: N/A Actividad 3.2: N/A

2016 Producto 1: 1. 85% de UNICAS conformadas en Ica el 2014 se mantienen operando. 2. 85% de UNICAS conformadas en Ayacucho el 2013 – 2014 se mantienen operando; y 60 nuevas UNICAS conformadas y en funcionamiento. 3. Al menos 65% de mujeres como miembros de UNICAS; Al menos 55% de mujeres en cargos directivos de UNICAS; Al menos 65% de los préstamos son otorgados a mujeres. Producto 2: Fomento de desarrollo empresarial. 1. 9 módulos de atención en actividad; 500 horas de capacitación impartidas; 400 consultorios empresariales; 4,000 empresarios capacitados.
A 15 junio 2016: Logro de resultados on track. Pendiente decision sobre Nuevo proyecto.

title.narrative: Gran Ecosistema Marino de la Corriente de Humboldt

description.narrative: Hacia la gestión del ecosistema de la Gran Corriente Marina de Humbold y acciones de adaptación.

title.narrative: Reporte de la Evaluación de Medio Termino

description.narrative: El objetivo del proyecto es avanzar hacia el manejo con enfoque de ecosistema para el Gran Ecosistema Marino de la Corriente de Humboldt (GEMCH) a través de un marco coordinado que fortalezca la gobernanza y el uso sostenible de los recursos marinos.
third-order administrative division
Environment - policy, planning and administration
Ecosystem-based management in the HCLME is advanced through a coordinated framework that provides for improved governance and the sustainable use of living marine resources and services
Agreement on and understanding of the ecosystem-level issues of the HCLME as they relate to management of living marine resources (LMR) and biodiversity conservation.

comment.narrative: Concerns relative to management of HCLME LMR limited to main shared commercial fishery stocks and impacts of environmental volatility
Countries agree on the scope and priority of ecosystem level issues & develop interventions to address them in the SAP including management of shared fisheries from an EBM perspective

The TDA is approved and the final draft SAP, based on agreements made with both Chile and Peru Technical Working Groups, has been sent to both countries for their final comments. These are due 5th August and the deadline for approval is mid September 2015.

description.narrative: Increase in the % of fisheries management decisions that are based on integrated information on multi-specific criteria and multi-disciplinary parameters, including natural and ENSO-related variability

comment.narrative:
Both Chile and Peru use single stock criteria for fisheries management, responses to ENSO are not precautionary but reactive
Note: A management decision matrix will be defined in year 1of project for monitoring this indicator

The shared anchovy fishery is managed using multi-specific criteria & multi -disciplinary parameters At least 50% of the decisions in management matrix include multi-specific criteria and multi-disciplinary parameters

After a series of workshops both countries are getting closer to EBFM regarding both the shared anchovy fishery and others. Towards the end of 2015 there will be another annual binational workshop regarding the shared anchovy fish stock. These meetings were frozen from 2008 to 2014 and restarted after the marine boarder dispute was settled at the Hague on 27.01.2014.

description.narrative: Increased area of priority coastal, coastal-marine and marine habitats in Peru & Chile that are under some form of legal protection that contributes to biodiversity conservation.

comment.narrative: Country & Habitat Area ha. Peru: Coastal 216,409 Marine 118,591 Chile: Seamounts MPA* 0 Seamounts VME** 0 *Marine Protected Area **Vulnerable Marine Ecosystem (VME)

Country & Habitat Area (ha.) Peru: Coastal 395,867 Marine 130,491 Chile: Seamounts MPA* 8,300 Seamounts VME** 507,000 *Estimated by 1.5 m round seamount apex **Under increased protection through VME protocol and fishing regulations; area estimated as per MPA x # of seamounts

The target level has been exceeded with 12,000Km2 of MPA confirmed in Chile along with studies to confirm where new MPAs should be established in years to come. In addition Management Plans have been drawn up for these new areas. In Peru Coastal Marine Spatial Planning work is going ahead and this process will draw on a range of studies carried out by this project and its partners regarding new protected areas. Furthermore all 118 seamounts are now protected including 3 in the Project's pilot site area in Chile as the Seamounts now form part of a Marine Park. Target exceeded in Chile. However additional MPAs * in Peru, although planned with Project assistance have as yet not been endorsed. * There are in fact no MPAs in Peru as the terminology used is Natural Protected Areas (NPA) and all current areas are a mix of land based areas with an extension of coastal waters associated.

description.narrative: Increase in the number of certifiable fisheries

comment.narrative: The necessary conditions for certifying a fishery are not yet in place
At least one fishery has the necessary elements for certification

The first artisanal fishery in the SE Pacific has been MSC certified in 2014 (Juan Fernandez Rock Lobster Fishery). Other fisheries including the Peruvian Anchovy, Mahi Mahi, and Scallops are being assessed. The project's target has been met.

description.narrative: % increased awareness in identified target groups, of the benefits of applying EBM

comment.narrative: % awareness of a defined number of target groups to be determined in the first 6months of the project
30% increase from the baseline value for each target group

EBM and EBFM among similar topics are now well embedded in both public and private sector mind-sets. Furthermore the IUCN 12 basic EMB principles are now well understood together with their means of implementation. The target has been met.

description.narrative: Planning and policy instruments for ecosystem-based management (EBM) of the HCLME are agreed and in place at regional and national levels
A Strategic Action Plan (SAP) developed based on up- dated ecosystem information and with an EBM approach is approved by both countries at the highest levels

comment.narrative: There is currently no common planning process or definition of priority actions Limited understanding of EBM
Complete SAP is endorsed at the highest levels by both countries

The SAP has been finalized based on stakeholder comments. The final draft is back with the technical working groups from both countries for final remarks due 5th August 2015. The intention is to incorporate these final comments and seek approval mid September 2015. Coastal Marine Spatial Planning has been promoted by the Project with NOAA assistance in both countries. A USD70,000 NOAA Grant has been endorsed to promote the CMSP process in Peru. A Ministerial Resolution has been achieved to promote the planning process See: http://www.minam.gob.pe/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/RM-N%C2%B0-189-2015-MINAM.pdf

description.narrative: National Action Plans (NAPs) developed within the SAP framework and approved in each country

comment.narrative: There are no national plans to prioritize actions for HCLM management. Existing plans are sector based
NAPs approved at the highest level in each country

Although the SAP has as yet not been approved new NAPs are being approved like the ICZM strategic planning resolution mentioned above:
http://www.minam.gob.pe/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/RM-N%C2%B0-189-2015-MINAM.pdf

description.narrative: % of the priority actions identified in plans that have secure financing: (a) regional level in SAP (b)national level in the NAP

comment.narrative: (a) 0 (b) Peru =0 Chile =0
(a)40% (b) Peru =60% Chile =60

A financial study has been carried out by the Project so as to suggest alternative ways of funding the Guano Islands and Capes National Reserve in Peru. This study is also of use to Chile regarding public-private methods of MPA funding.

description.narrative: Existence of short, medium and long-term targets for marine & coastal habitat conservation

comment.narrative: National protected area system strategies do not have specific targets for coastal marine conservation
NPAS identify priority to reduce habitat representativity gaps and have specific targets & implementation strategies

Conservation objectives have been established in Peru and work to be finalized before the end of 2015 in Chile (Management Plans for MUMPAs and Vulnerable Area identification work) similar objectives will have been announced at the Our Ocean International event 5th & 6th October 2015 in Valparaiso, Chile.

description.narrative: Number of sectors represented and level of officials that participate in the national inter-sectoral committees

comment.narrative: To be measured in yr 1 as NIC do not yet exist
The numbers of sectors represented and levels when NIC are first formed, are maintained and strengthened throughout the project

Participants within the National Intersectoral Committees continue to increase with new private sector and local NGO permanent membership. In addition work within the Communications Strategy implementation networks have brought more Civil Society Organisation groups into the cooperation framework.

description.narrative: Institutional capacities strengthened for SAP implementation and for up-scaling pilot interventions to the system level
1. % of effective information exchanges in protocols defined within the framework of the Ecosystem Information System (EIS)

comment.narrative: Currently, each government manages independent Geographical Information Systems (GIS) with limited information exchange.
70% of protocols for information exchange are functioning at least at minimal levels

Many information exchange mechanisms are now in place via the Communications Strategy and communications experts within all counterpart entities (brought together by the Amig@s del Mar initiative) See project website. Target reached.

description.narrative: % of staff profiles and procedures that are aligned with EBM in key institutions (i.e., CONAMA, MINAM, SUBPESCA, Vice-Minist. de PesquerÃ­a)

comment.narrative: <10% of staff in IFOP, IMARPE have profiles aligned with needs for EBM Staff profiles & procedures for EBM will be determined in yr 1 once standards have been set based on agreed EBM definition

20% of staff in IFOP, IMARPE have profiles aligned with needs for EBM 70% of the research projects for resource management follow ecosystemic criteria Targets for other institutions to be determined in year 1

Targets reached. The level of awareness within both public and private entities has increased dramatically due to both project capacity building work and the initiatives of both government funding programmes.

description.narrative: Key institutions (MINAM CONAMA, SUBPESCA), have the capacities and internal processes to prioritize the creation of new MPAs and to manage them effectively.

comment.narrative: Baseline to be established with institutional capacity scorecard values applied to relevant institutions on each country
30% above baseline values

Management plans for new MPAs are being finalized: in the case of Chile this amounts to new MPAs (Multiple Use) in addition to the identification of vulnerable areas to be given protection status in the future. Similar work in Peru has centred on the Guano Islands and Capes National Reserve (RNSIIPG) with additional areas being prioritized for MUMPA status.

description.narrative: Procedures defined and adopted to promote good fisheries practices and improve market competitiveness within the framework of the HCLME

comment.narrative: There are no procedures for promoting good fisheries practices in relation to market competitiveness in either country
At least two mechanisms are adopted that promote good practices and improve market competitiveness within the framework of the HCLME

The Chilean Juan Fernandez Rock Lobster fishery received MSC certification early 2015. Market competitiveness has also been promoted for macro algae added value production from a 23km extension of algal beds in southern Peru and habitat restoration work covering 50ha in Paracas Bay Peru. Management plans for the co-management of other important fisheries including scallops in northern Peru have been established.

description.narrative: Improved understanding of the benefits of ecosystem goods and services of artisanal fisher representatives that participate in fisheries fora (as a proxy indicator of potential compliance with regulatory frameworks)

comment.narrative: Baseline level of understanding of ecosystem benefits in will be measured in at project start
Increase of 30% above baseline values

In 2015 an Economic Valuation of the Goods and Services provided by the HCLME was finalized with a USD19.5 billion value placed on their annual delivery. Value addition work in both countries and analyses carried out under the TDA-SAP process have shown that while fisheries landing volumes are decreasing year-on-year their value are increasing.

description.narrative: Implementation of priority MPA & fisheries management tools provides knowledge of options for enhanced protection of HCLME and SAP implementation
Advances in adopting EBM for the shared anchovy stock as measured by the increase in agreed on and coordinated program of activities

comment.narrative: Current agreement between IFOP and IMARPE only includes information exchange on stock evaluations and reproductive parameters for main pelagic commercial stocks
Coordinated management agreement includes the use of multi-specific criteria and multi-disciplinary parameters for the establishment of each country\\\\\\\'s TAC for the shared stock

IFOP Chile has recently made a joint assessment of the shared anchovy stock based on their data and that posted on the IMARPE website, thus demonstrating the importance of information sharing. Seminars and workshops on top predators and methods of shared stock evaluation continued in the reporting period. Courses on the bioeconomics of fish stock recovery have been successfully delivered in both Chile and Peru by a Chilean fisheries biologist. This target only partially achieved.

description.narrative: Adoption of coordinated management measures for the shared stock, such as closures, quotas and exclusion areas

comment.narrative: Each country uses independent criteria for managing their part of the shared stock
Countries use the same criteria for establishing TACs, fishing seasons and exclusion areas

Work towards the use of the same evaluation criteria, or at least ways of ensuring improved correlation between the methodologies use, continues. However as yet the two countries do not use the same criteria. Target partially achieved.

description.narrative: Increase in hectares of the coastal-marine interface under improved management - measured by RNSIIPG Master Plan and the tools for monitoring and management effectiveness measurement

comment.narrative: RNSIIPG has not yet been established. See ProDoc for METT score by category. Capes and islands of the guano systems are currently managed from an extractive perspective only targeting guano birds as conservation priorities worthy of protection.

RNSIIPG established with a fully developed Management Plan See ProDoc for METT score by category. The GEF METT has been used to establish initial baseline and target values but a more specific M&E tool for marine areas will be developed in the FSP and will also be used to measure management effectiveness gains

Zoning work for the RNSIIPG has been advanced this reporting period. In addition a financial management plan for the protected area has been designed. A study using drone technology has been finalized to assist SERNANP and AGRORURAL to make decisions about the opening and closing of guano extraction times so as to have a minimal impact on seabirds. The METT score will be updated at the start of 2016 as part of the Final Review process. The RNSIIPG Master Plan will be approved at the end of 2015 while acknowledging that some work will remain at a range of the 33 sites not included as pilot areas under the GEF-UNDP Humboldt project.

description.narrative: Identification of equivalency in conservation management options (PAs) for coastal and marine environments in both countries

comment.narrative: Peru has no specific protected area categories for marine areas, but uses terrestrial categories, that follow a gradient from direct to indirect resource use with no fully intangible protected areas. Chile has three categories for marine areas (Marine Reserves, Marine Parks and MUMPAS). These management schemes and categories are not equivalent for both countries
SNAP and SINANPE MPA conservation categories defined, equated and based on a common concept for both countries

Work is on-going regarding a comparison of protected area legislation between the two countries. To date Peru still does not have MPAs or MUMPAs, TURFs and other territorial based co-management areas. Nevertheless the project has been instrumental in promoting Coastal Marine Spatial Planning work assisted by trainers from NOAA. This work will continue during the remainder of the Project and after closure with a direct link to the new Coastal Fisheries Initiative in Ecuador and Peru with the possibility of drawing on Chilean experience with MPAs, MUMPAs and TURFs. The GEF-UNDP Humboldt Project is developing a management plans for a new 12,000km2 MUMPA area in Chile.

description.narrative: Number of best management practices developed in the project pilot sites that are up-scaled to other protected areas

comment.narrative: a) Peru: 3 other sites in the RNSIIPG with management committees and plans b) Chile: at least one other canyon or seamount in the process of adoption the management options

Targets achieved. a) Good management plans regarding the start and end of guano harvesting are ready for use at all 33 RNSIIPG sites in Peru. Similarly the financial management options are available for all RNSIIPG sites and possibly Chile as well. The use of drones for assessing wildlife in isolated areas has proved to be effective. b) Marine parks have been established around two seamounts in Chile with all seamounts receiving a degree of protection under the 2013 fisheries Law.

description.narrative: Implementation of pilot MPAs that underpin ecosystem conservation and resilience

1. Increase in management effectiveness of the pilot MPAs measured a) in Peru with a) Management Plans b) b) with the Declaration of the area in Chile c)Management effectiveness tracking tool (METT) METT Poor= < 25%; Fair=2650%:, Good= 5176%:; Excellent= 77100%

comment.narrative:
(a) 3 pilot areas in Peru do not have management plans; in Chile only specific fisheries (orange roughy) are currently managed in sea mounts (b) METT values Peru (See ProDoc Logframe for METT score by category)
Chile Seamount 1& 2 METT 5/63 = 8% Poor

(a) All 3 pilots in Peru with approved management plans; Ecosystem-based management strategy for 2 sea mounts agreed on by relevant stakeholders (b) (b) METT values Peru (See ProDoc Logframe for METT score by category)
Chile Seamount 1&2 METT 30% (Fair or more)

Targets partially achieved. The three Pilot Sites in Peru have baseline surveys, conservation plans and zoning carried out although these have not as yet been fully approved in a 33 site Management Plan. The Management Plans for the Seamounts (as Marine Parks) within the MUMPA area (JF6 - is actually outside the MUMPA area and will have to be considered separately) will be submitted semester II 2015. As mentioned above METT results will be updated early 2016 in relation to the final review process.

description.narrative: 2. Reduction in the incidence of illegal extractive activities in restricted areas established in the management plans of RNSIIPG pilot sites

comment.narrative: No. of reports of illegal extractive activities will be measured once zoning of pilots is complete
Reduction of 50% for RNSIIPG

Capacity building work with the management groups at each of the 33 RNSIIPG sites has successfully provided a mechanism for local level monitoring control and surveillance systems to reduce illegal activities like the use of explosives, poisons and illegal fishing gear in the areas surrounding and within the National Reserve. Although not as yet quantified via the monitoring reports a reduction of illegal activities is evident.

description.narrative: 3. % management costs of the pilot areas protected that have secure financing (a) a) RNSIIPG pilots (b) b) Seamounts

comment.narrative: As neither the RNSIIPG nor the Seamount MPA has been established there are currently no specific management costs.
a) 100% of the RNSIIPG pilots management costs covered of which at least 50% is from resources other than GoP b) Seamount have identified sources for 100% management costs

a) A financial management plan has been produced for the RNSIIPG as an update to the version created in 2009 prior to the RNSIIPG establishment. At present 50% of the RNSIIPG costs are covered by tourist activities associated with the 300,000 visitors per annum to the Ballestas Islands. A number which clearly puts a high level of pressure on the wildlife and increases the risk of marine accidents caused by the high speed transport of tourists to and from the Islands. b) JF5 management costs will be included in the MUMPA management plan under development throughout 2015. However JF6 and Bajo O'Higgins, while protected under new legislation and the fact that commercial fishing boats national and foreign are obliged to carry GPS devices when operating under license in the Chilean EEZ, do not have management costs other than the work carried out by Fisheries Patrol vessels.

description.narrative: 4. Ecosystem-based management strategy for sea canyons agreed on by the relevant stakeholders

comment.narrative: No specific plans for sea canyons exist
Approved management strategy for sea canyons of the HCLME
While assessment work exists in both countries this is just at a very superficial level. There will be no approved sea canyon management strategy approved by the end of this phase of the project.

description.narrative: 5. Populations of flagship species at pilots Species will be selected in yr 1

comment.narrative: Population levels (distribution and abundance) as estimated in yr 1 for selected flagship and/or indicator species in pilots
Populations maintain at least the same levels as at the beginning of the project or are increasing

Data for all species is available in both countries but not shared wither within country entities or between the two countries. Data collection also comes from a range of sources both public and NGO: TNC, WWF Birdlife international). Further work needs to be carried out to coordinate datasets with ENSO occurrences. The use of drones will greatly assist this process.

Energy - power generation
To reduce CO2 emissions through the implementation of a (mandatory) energy efficiency standards and labels program
A) Change in annual sales towards average higher efficiency appliances (lower unit energy consumption, UEC)

comment.narrative: A) See UEC table in footnote below

A) Reduction in average UEC (see table in footnote below) of selected household appliances: (refrigerators, refrigerator-freezers and freezers; water heaters; air conditioning equipment and washing machines) and electric motors.
The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

description.narrative: B) Share of non-compliant products

comment.narrative: B) N/A (there is no mandatory S&L)

B) Based on the surveys of output 2.1, the role of ´informal ´ trade will be quantified. Based on this a ´non-compliant ´ product will be defined. A preliminary aim is at least 50% should be compliant by the end of the project.
The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

description.narrative: C) GHG emission trends

comment.narrative: C) Annual electricity demand will grow to 1000 TJ by 2018 and corresponding GHG emissions (see Figure 1 in UNDP Prodoc)

C) The Referential Plan mentions a savings potential of 54 TJ annually by the year 2018 with corresponding cumulative GHG reduction of 35.6 million tCO2 over the period 2009-2018, of which around 5% (1,780 ktCO2) due to electricity savings by consumers (excluding lighting), motors and efficient water heaters. The estimate of direct and indirect emissions (1,217 ktCO2 over the period 2011-2018) fits within the Referential Plan ´s projections. See also Section 1 in the UNDP ProDoc for more details.
The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

description.narrative: D) Amount of CO2 emissions avoided directly and indirectly

comment.narrative: The indicator cannot be measured yet at this point of the project implementation

description.narrative: Enhanced capacities of key public and private agencies to design, implement and enforce a mandatory S&L programme
E) Status of programs in key public agencies to implement effective mandatory S&L

comment.narrative: E) Insufficient implementation of S&L program which is in guidelines only
E) New policy provisions and compliance checking, enforcement and outreach programs adopted that reflect international â€œbest practicesâ€?

The Directive Committee of the project has held meetings in which it has received substantial information provided by the different consultancies/ studies undertaken during the project implementation. This learning process has enabled their capabilities for designing, implementing and enforcing a mandatory S&L program. The committee is formed by key entities in the matter, such as the Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Energy and Mines, Ministry of Production, Ministry of Economy and Finance, Ministry of External Commerce and Tourism, INDECOPI (National Institute for the defense of the competence and protection of intellectual property), SUNAT (National Superintendence of Customs and Tax Administration).

description.narrative: Market transformation strategy implemented with public and private sector involvement, based on consolidated information on the market structure
F) Level of info available to define energy consumption in label categories and for measuring project impact

comment.narrative: F) Data available in MINEMâ€™s database, but needs to be updated and expanded
F) Regularly updated data on annual sale and energy consumption and technology characteristics of different appliances per energy classes available

A study was concluded in December, 2014, with the following topics: a) structure, evolution and projection of the market related to energy equipment (refrigerator, washing machine, dryer, conditioner air machine, water heater, electric motors and boiler); b) data base of energy consumption and end use of technologies; and c) measurement of environmental, energy and economic impacts for efficiency energy labeling

description.narrative: G) Status of recommendations contributing to institutional sustainability (transformation strategy)

comment.narrative: G) Data available in MINEMâ€™s database, but needs to be updated and expanded

G) Regularly updated data on annual sale and energy consumption and technology characteristics of different appliances per energy classes available for public use (with finalized market monitoring methodology)

The elaboration of the strategy depends on others processes, some of them are concluded and others are in process; therefore, the strategy has not been designed yet and is scheduled for next year. The status of such processes is:
- A study related to market aspects and energy consumption, which was detailed in a point before, was concluded in December, 2014.
- Two international bids have been launched: 1) Diagnosis and Evaluation of Laboratories for Labeling; and 2) Development of a System of Conformity Assessment for the Certification of Energy Efficiency Labeling. Currently, the proposals are under evaluation.
- A study on the management, treatment and disposal of solid waste and emissions from energy equipment; the study has been launched as part of a bidding process.

description.narrative: Strengthened legal framework for mandatory S&L and endorsed final Technical Regulations
H) Status of decision-making regarding introduction of mandatory EE S&L

comment.narrative: H) Mandatory MEPS exist for CFLs; voluntary labels and MEPS for ballasts, cloth washers, fluorescent lamps, refrigerators and freezers, air conditioners and electric water heaters
H) Decree(s) signed by the Council of Ministers on Technical regulations making labels (and/or MEPs) mandatory in the refrigerators, freezers, water heaters , washing machines and electric motors

9 projects of technical regulations related to energy efficiency were concluded at the end of December, 2014. The projects were related to the following equipment: fluorescent lamps, ballasts for fluorescent lamps used in lighting for domestic purpose, refrigerators, washing machines, dryers, conditioner air machines, water heaters, electric motors and boilers. The regulation projects were published to allow the public participation during their approval process. Up to date, more than 600 public opinions have been received and evaluated. In this context, meetings with the technical body and the decision makers to reach a consensus for the approval of such regulations are ongoing.

description.narrative: Heightened consumer awareness and acceptance of S&L programme.
I) Priority of different criteria used by customers in their purchasing decision and of private sector in marketing their products

comment.narrative: I) No emphasis among the consumers (and sales personnel) on energy efficiency aspects and life cycle costs when purchasing and marketing new appliances
I) Beside the initial purchasing price, energy efficiency and life-cycle costs have become a key criteria for purchasing decisions, guided by the energy label

A communication strategy has been designed and a bidding process for its implementation has been launched. The strategy is targeted at consumers, to increase their awareness and acceptance to the S&L program.

description.narrative: Information and knowledge on S&L programme generated and shared
J) The level of information available for monitoring and evaluation and adaptive management

comment.narrative: J) N/A
J) Adequate information available for adaptive management and measuring the impact.

A financial audit was carried out for the period 2012-2014. The auditor recommended keeping the control and follow up as part of the project management. The quarterly reports of the physical progress of the project were handed over timely.

comment.narrative: - 8 instituciones nacionales cumplen con actualizar: Portales de Transparencia. - 12 medios de comunicación publican La Página Municipios Transparentes. - 6 Gobiernos Regionales cumplen con Portales de Transparencia. - 2 Municipalidades Provinciales cumplen con Portales de Transparencia. - 12 quejas recibidas a través de la Línea Gratuita de Acceso a la Información Pública. - 4,242 Autoridades y Funcionarios Públicos, representantes del Poder Judicial y Periodistas capacitados. - 2,353 Ciudadanos capacitados.

- 7 instituciones nacionales, 3 Gobiernos Regionales y 115 Municipalidades Provinciales y Distritales cumplen con actualizar Portales de Transparencia. - 6 Medios de comunicación Nac. y 10 Reg. publican la Página Municipios Transparentes - 30 quejas recibidas a través de la Línea Gratuita de Acceso a la Información Pública. - 200 Autoridades y Funcionarios Públicos del Gobierno Central, 90 mujeres, son capacitadas en Ley 27806 y GA. - 100 funcionarios capacitados en Ley 27806 y GA. - 100 Funcionarios ediles, 40 mujeres, capacitados en la Ley 27806 y GA. - 160 ciudadanos, 60 mujeres capacitados en Audiencias Públicas del CPP.- 5 entidades del Gobierno Central solicitan asesoramiento en Directiva Interna de Transparencia y GA.

Julio 2015 90 autoridades y funcionarios públicos capacitados por el CPP en la implementación de la Ley 28706. 6 quejas/consultas recibidas a tráves de la linea gratuita. 1 GR Piura actualizó parcialmente la información de su portal de transparencia.
proyección Dic 2015 Peruvian Press Council (CPP) have contributed to support National, Regional and Local Governments to accomplish with law duties of transparency and information access. description.narrative: Población y sus medios de vida con vulnerabilidades reducidas frente al riesgo de desastres, a través de la mejora de la implementación del PLANAGERD
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

- Número de guías metodológicas para asegurar la coordinación interinstitucional a través de la formulación de herramientas para la GRD - Plan de Contingencia de la Red Humanitaria Nacional ante escenario de sismo y tsunami en Lima y Callao - Número de Sistemas de Información en GRD mejorados. - Número de herramientas para la mejora de las capacidades de la respuesta humanitaria en telecomunicaciones y asistencia alimentaria - Número de planes y protocolos para la respuesta humanitaria en los niveles subnacional, nacional e internacional ante desastres de gran magnitud - Número de quebradas que cuentan con planes de preparación y planes de respuesta adecuados incluyendo enfoque de género y generacional - Estrategia de comunicación pública en la cuenca del río Rímac diseñada e implementada participativamente

comment.narrative: • No existe un mecanismo de coordinación adecuadamente implementado ante escenarios de riesgo que involucren a más de un gobierno regional o local y la RHN. • No se han puesto en marcha aún mecanismos para involucrar al sector privado en la GRD. • Limitada capacidad para liderar y manejar las telecomunicaciones interinstitucionales durante emergencias, ii) limitada infraestructura para telecomunicaciones, iii) ausencia de guías protocolos y estándares, iv) personal con limitada capacidad en TIC. • Necesidad de mejorar capacidades de las autoridades en evaluación de necesidades en ayuda alimentaria. • Existen varios sistemas de información relacionados con la GRD que no se encuentran integrados. • Alta vulnerabilidad de las comunidades incrementada por la falta de preparación en GRD, particularmente en la inclusión de los enfoque de género y generacional y el mínimo involucramiento de la población y sus líderes. • El SINAGERD no cuenta con una estrategia de comunicación con productos orientados a audiencias específicas y que integre los enfoques comunicacionales de las entidades nacionales que lo conforman.

-5 guías metodológicas para la coordinación interinstitucional a través de la formulación de herramientas para la GRD -1 plan de contingencia de la Red Humanitaria Nacional ante escenario de sismo y tsunami en Lima y Callao -3 sistemas de información en GRD mejorados -2 herramientas para la mejora de las capacidades de la respuesta humanitaria en telecomunicaciones y asistencia alimentaria. -4 planes y protocolos para la respuesta humanitaria en los niveles subnacional, nacional e internacional ante desastres de gran magnitud -2 quebradas con planes de preparación y planes de respuesta adecuados incluyendo enfoque de género y generacional. -1 estrategia de comunicación pública en la cuenca del río Rímac diseñada e implementada participativamente.

Project was not operational in 2014 - En desarrollo el Plan de Operaciones de Emergencia de la Región Lima, y su articulación a través de protocolos con los Planes de Operaciones de Emergencias de Lima Metropolitana y El Callao, en base a la cual se desarrollará la guía para la formulación de Planes de Operaciones de Emergencia. En elaboración el Plan de Continuidad Operativa de la MML y la respectiva guía para gobiernos locales. - Asesoramiento a la Región La Libertad sobre mecanismos de financiamiento de actividades y proyectos de emergencia de cara al FEN, conjuntamente con la SGRD-PCM. - En elaboración Guía Metodológica para Misiones Multisectoriales de Evaluación Rápida de Necesidades Humanitarias de la Red Humanitaria Nacional. - Plan de Contingencia de la RHN ante escenario FEN 2015-2016 en elaboración. - 02 Reuniones efectuadas del Clúster de Seguridad Alimentaria y Nutrición. - Se han establecido las especificaciones técnicas de los equipos necesarios para el reforzamiento del sistema de telecomunicaciones de emergencia en Lima y El Callao, en coordinación con INDECI y la PNP - Se ha brindado asistencia técnica para el desarrollo de los ejercicios de simulación ante sismos y tsunami al Gobierno regional de Lima, al Gobierno regional del Callao y a la Municipalidad Metropolitana de Lima. En Trujillo se han desarrollado dos ejercicios de simulación en respuesta alimentaria ante emergencias. - Plan de capacitaciones comunitarias formulado. Levantamiento de Línea de Base con enfoque de género y generacional en proceso. (UNFPA-UNV). Coordinación con Proyecto Aliados contra las Inundaciones. Soluciones Prácticas-Zurich. Coordinación preliminar con IGP para instalación de SAT en Quebrada Castilla. Cinco Talleres de Asistencia Alimentaria en Emergencias en Trujillo, Cañete, Santa Eulalia y Huacho dirigido a líderes, profesionales y estudiantes para mejorar sus conocimientos sobre los procedimientos establecidos de la ayuda alimentaria por parte del estado. - Pre

title.narrative: PRODOC Apoyo Loreto firmado Parte 2 de 2

description.narrative: Proceso de recuperación de la Región Loreto formulado y en marcha
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Por lo menos una mesa de coordinación y articulación de los tomadores de decisión de distintos niveles territoriales y sectoriales, sector privado y sociedad civil creada Un marco de recuperación formulado y validado que incluya la priorización de PIP Por lo menos 20 funcionarios de nivel regional y local acceden a capacitación para una adecuada gestión financiera del proceso de recuperación

comment.narrative: SINAGERD con arreglos normativos e institucionales definidos Estrategia de Gestión Financiera del Riesgo de Desastres Estudio de Ciudades Sostenibles de la ciudad de Iquitos No se cuenta con mecanismos interinstitucionales de toma de decisión para la GRD No se cuenta con un análisis de las brechas en temas de recuperación No se cuenta con un marco de recuperación post-inundación Débiles capacidades para la gestión financiera de la GRD
Mesa interinstitucional Metodología de análisis de brechas Balance regional de necesidades de recuperación Proyectos prioritarios identificados 1 taller de capacitación

Project was not operational in 2014 - Se cuenta con 2 mesas interinstitucionales instaladas a nivel regional, de acuerdo a lo establecido en los dispositivos legales peruano en materia de GRD: el Grupo de Trabajo y la Plataforma de Defensa Civil. Además se ha impulsado y se cuenta con: 1. Mesa de Educación, para las coordinaciones de las acciones de preparación de las instituciones involucradas en el sector, frente al escenario del FEN en la región Loreto. 2. Grupos de Trabajo de las Municipalidades Distritales de Maynas, Punchana, San Juan Bautista y Belén. - Se ha elaborado la metodología para el análisis de necesidades de recuperación con enfoque de género e intercultural elaborada en coordinación con actores locales y regionales y sobre la base del PDNA de PNUD, que servirá para realizar el balance regional de necesidades de recuperación y el marco de recuperación. Además, en alianza con el proyecto 86467 "Fortaleciendo las capacidades del SINAGERD en el desarrollo e implementación de instrumentos de GRD orientados a la recuperación considerando la perspectiva de género", se ha desarrollado el Taller de Capacitación en “Preparativos y planificación de la Recuperación y Evaluación de Necedades Post Desastres en el contexto del Fenómeno El Niño” 2015 – 2016. La información levantada durante el taller constituye insumo para la elaboración del Plan de Recuperación. - Se ha realizado un taller de capacitación a los integrantes de la Plataforma Regional de Defensa Civil, en temas de Planificación de instrumentos de respuesta, Programa Presupuestales por resultado (PPR 068, FONIPREL, PIPs), EDAN, SINPAD, en el marco del proceso de recuperación. El Taller se denominó “fortalecimiento de capacidades en mecanismos financieros regional y locales para la gestión reactiva del riesgo” desarrollado del 21 al 23 de setiembre, donde participaron más de 50 personas
Mesa interinstitucional Marco de recuperación con procedimientos de seguimiento y arreglos institucionales 1 PIP formulado 20 funcionarios capacitados

- Apoyo al fortalecimiento de los espacios de coordinación, incorporando el proceso de recuperación de medios de vida, entre las autoridades del Gobierno Central, Regional y Local, sector privado y sociedad civil. Consolidación del espacio de Grupo de Trabajo de Gestión de Riesgo de Desastres y las Plataformas de Defensa Civil, del Gobierno Regional de Loreto, de la Municipalidad Provincial de Maynas y Municipalidades Distritales de Belén, Punchana, San Juan Bautista, como parte del proceso de coordinación a nivel regional y local para la evaluación de necesidades y formulación de los procesos de recuperación y del desarrollo. Reuniones de coordinación con diferentes niveles del Gobierno Central (MEF, MVSC, MINEDU, MINSA, CEPLAN, ANA, MINAM, INDECI, CENEPRED, etc.); Gobierno Regional (GORE Loreto); Gobiernos Provinciales (MP Maynas, MP Yurimaguas) y Gobiernos Locales (MD San Juna Bautista, MD Punchana, MD Belén) e integrantes del Proyecto CERF (agencias del Sistema de Naciones Unidas). Reunión de coordinación con los integrantes de la Cámara de Comercio, industria y turismo de Loreto, para el desarrollo de actividades con los gobiernos regionales. - Metodología del marco estratégico para la recuperación con enfoque de género y pobreza formulado de manera interinstitucional de acuerdo a prioridades identificadas mediante análisis de brechas. Diseño de la metodología para el análisis de necesidades de recuperación con enfoque de género e intercultaridad en coordinación con actores locales y nacionales. Elaboración de un balance a nivel regional de necesidades, respuesta y brechas. Elaboración de un diseño de procedimientos de seguimiento al proceso de recuperación y estrategia de información pública de avances y brechas. Asistencia técnica proporcionada para la identificación y priorización de proyectos de mitigación y prevención del riesgo de inundaciones y de recuperación en zonas afectadas priorizadas aseg
